p: Two studies (9%) brought an analysis of intangible costs, represented by the Quality- Adjusted Life Years (QALY). In Panama [ 16] there was an average of 67% QALY during the worst days of illness in 2005, while in Malaysia [ 19] the average was 60% QALY in 2009. And three studies (14%) brought indirect cost analysis, represented by the Disability-Adjusted Life Years (DALYs). In Mexico [ 22] the annual disease rate averaged 65 DALYs per million inhabitants between 2010 and 2011. In Cambodia [ 28] the annual disease rate ranged from 24,3 to 100,6 DALYs per hundred thousand inhabitants between 2007 and 2008. The Americas presented an estimated 73,000 DALYs, with 131 DALYs per million inhabitants in 2004, the highest number per million inhabitants [ 18].
